name: Clark, Jason
title: Escher Grotesk
challenge_solution: The challenge was to devise an engaging and unique way to drive traffic to VIA Studio's new website, post rebrand.   We solved this challenge by designing Escher Grotesk, a geometrically-impossible typeface inspired by VIA's rebrand, to be a free promotional download on VIA's new site.

name: Goodman, Glenn
title: GE Profile Photography
challenge_solution: GE Profile incorporates smart home technology and cutting-edge features into every appliance to make daily life simpler. In turn, both product and set photography needed to be captured in a way to communicate a high-tech lifestyle without being cold or barren. Using unique angles and focused but dramatic lighting, The Power Agency team was able to develop a system of photography that was unique, interesting and, most importantly - showed off the core brand tenets and product features in a memorable way.

name: Hartley, Emmy
title: Thomas S. Moore Bourbon Branding
challenge_solution: A new, innovative brand of bourbon from Barton 1792 Distillery, named after a historic bourbon visionary. First, we designed the glass bottle itself, which is inspired by Thomas S. Moore’s grandfather, a renowned craftsman who helped build the famous St. Joseph Cathedral. The shape of this bottle has an architectural quality, taking cues from iconic columns and intricate trim of the cathedral. The label features a horse brand icon in honor of one of Moore’s earliest brands. The brand’s many flourishes and motifs were heavily inspired by vintage advertisements and stationery from the Thomas S. Moore archives.

name: Nelson, Cher
title: American Civil War Museum
challenge_solution: Solid Light was challenged to re-envision what a Civil War museum experience could be. With the unapologetic statement that the Civil War should be interpreted as a war over slavery, the project presents a more-inclusive, human-focused narrative of America: enslaved and self-emancipated, soldier and civilian, and children, men, and women.  Working to shatter and rebuild visitors expectations of the story, Solid Light employed angular forms, custom structures, juxtaposed materials and artifacts, colorized historic photography, and bold projection-mapped immersive media. This new museum experience presents a landscape of war-time choices, real human connection, and a narrative aimed at resetting the conversation.

name: Goodman, Glenn
title: Passionist Earth & Spirit Center - Logo
challenge_solution: The Passionist Earth & Spirit Center is a nonprofit, interfaith spirituality center that’s deeply rooted in the idea that everything is interconnected. In 2020, they needed a new logo to update their image to appeal to a more diverse audience. This design focuses on a tree, which communicates a connection to the earth while still reaching for the heavens. The logo also conveys the beauty and movement of a single brush stroke to hint at the spiritual growth students will discover during their time at the PESC — growth that will help them to reach beyond what they thought possible.

name: Ostertag, Charles
title: Louisville COVID-19 Match
challenge_solution: Red Tag funded all advertising, public relations, web and branding support for Louisville COVID-19 Match, a local nonprofit that connects elderly and high-risk people with healthy, low-risk community members to help with deliveries and wellness checks.  The agency ran a paid Facebook campaign featuring 15-second video ads to raise awareness and match those in need with a surplus of low-risk volunteers.  Facebook Case Study: https://www.facebook.com/business/stories/resilient-business/red-tag-digital  Website: https://lc19match.com/#/

name: Clark, Jason
title: Revelry Rebrand
challenge_solution: The challenge was to make Relevry's mission (To provide accessibility to art, for both artists and customers) evident in their branding. Along with infusing their values within their brand, they wanted a more serious and prideful look and feel.  We provided them with an elevated brand identity, complete with language that supports their mission. The identity feels mature, elegant, and proud. Not only does the joyous symbolism of the bluebird remain, but the addition of the branch represents the support Revelry gives to the art community and the bird’s gaze was switched from left to right, representing forward-thinking and optimism.

name: Clark, Jason
title: Celestial Bodies of the Past Present & Future
challenge_solution: Astrology is more popular now than ever, and with this rise in popularity, there has also been a rise in astro-tech. Star chart calculators are a dime a dozen, but none of them capture the simplicity, warmth, or charm of the old school pulp magazines.  Our star chart merges those vintage astrological vibes with 21st century technology. The API we built uses the Swiss Ephemeris to determine the rotation of each of the twelve houses as well as each planet, and with that data we were able to arrange the chart by rotating each piece to match the reported position.

name: Clark, Jason
title: VIA Rebrand
challenge_solution: We’re not the same agency we were 10 years ago. And that’s by design. Today, we are an agency focused on transforming brands through strategy, design, development & externally our brand no longer mirrored who we now are and where we’re headed. It was time for a change.  VIA Studio needed to take a leap forward towards a more sophisticated and authoritative look. Playing with perspective, the new mark creates an impossible shape that’s an intriguing mix of real and imaginary. The overall composition is a nod to our previous logo but with an abstract approach.

name: Hartley, Emmy
title: Freddie's Ginger Ale Packaging
challenge_solution: Our objective was to distill the personality of local legend and Buffalo Trace Distillery Tour Guide Freddie Johnson, and translate it into the type of folk-hero iconography that will turn Freddie’s into a national soda brand.   The design elements are minimal, fun, and playful with bottles featuring illustrations of Johnson and a word balloon of his favorite lines such as “Hey Daddy-O!”  The bottlenecks feature more Freddiespeak, such as “How Cool is That?” “Stay Cool!” or “Isn’t That Neat?”   Freddie’s Old Fashioned Soda is available in Root Beer, Ginger Ale, and Ginger Beer, differentiated by brown, white and green bottles.

name: Thieneman, Savannah
title: University of Louisville Positive Leadership App
challenge_solution: Here at Slingshot, we know all about making solutions fun. We worked with UofL to come up with engaging features, making the app feel more like a game and less like homework. We also wanted to ensure the integrity of true meaningful leadership development was maintained.  Objectives Conduct research to uncover the needs of students and leaders. Create an iOS and Android mobile app to make leadership development accessible. Gamify the app to make activities fun and engaging. Connect community leaders to solicit feedback and encouragement. Integrate with the user’s calendar to map exercises to events.
credit_1: Slingshot Design Team (Rachel Foster, Cheyenne Nolan)

name: Thieneman, Savannah
title: New Roots Fresh Stop Markets
challenge_solution: New roots were the winners of our Launch initiative, so we knew they were up for the challenge. Together, we decided to create a mobile app that not only helped new shareholders sign up, but also reminded them to order and pick up new shares.  Objectives Design and build a mobile app for both iOS and Android Remind shareholders of upcoming markets and orders Show the ideal share price per shareholder Add payment options through Credit Card, ACH, and SNAP Empower users to make donations
credit_1: Slingshot Design Team (Rachel Foster, Cheyenne Nolan)

name: Thieneman, Savannah
title: New Roots Fresh Stop Markets
challenge_solution: New roots were the winners of our Launch initiative, so we knew they were up for the challenge. Together, we decided to create a mobile app that not only helped new shareholders sign up, but also reminded them to order and pick up new shares.  Objectives Design and build a mobile app for both iOS and Android Remind shareholders of upcoming markets and orders Show the ideal share price per shareholder Add payment options through Credit Card, ACH, and SNAP Empower users to make donations
credit_1: Slingshot Design Team (Rachel Foster, Cheyenne Nolan)

name: Hartley, Emmy
title: Keeneland Fall Ale
challenge_solution: Keeneland, Lexington's historic Thoroughbred Racetrack, collaborated with a local brewer, Country Boy Brewing, to create a branded ale promoting it's Fall Race Meet . Our assignment was to design packaging that conjured up the environment and the season and set the mood for this special brew.  Our design choices were inspired by the look and mood of the sun shining on a barley field in the late summer/early fall. We chose the golden color palette and wheat laurel icon to represent the brand’s heritage. Looking closer, you'll find an intricate design scheme including detailed sketches of Keeneland’s historic grounds.

name: Hartley, Emmy
title: VisitLEX Illustrated Postcards
challenge_solution: Lexington has plenty to offer travelers, even in these “uncertain times.” But, with so many restrictions in place, conveying that fact with photography/videography is a challenge. And people wisely don’t trust brands when it comes to their safety. They do, however, trust their friends and family. These illustrated digital postcards, with their playful graphics and clever copy, gave locals a shareable tool to encourage their stir crazy loved ones to unplug for a bit and have some safe, socially distanced fun in the Bluegrass. Plus they’re pretty. Who doesn’t like a pretty postcard?

name: Hartley, Emmy
title: Thomas S. Moore Bourbon Packaging
challenge_solution: A new, innovative brand of bourbon from Barton 1792 Distillery, named after a historic bourbon visionary. First, we designed the glass bottle itself, which is inspired by Thomas S. Moore’s grandfather, a renowned craftsman who helped build the famous St. Joseph Cathedral. The shape of this bottle has an architectural quality, taking cues from iconic columns and intricate trim of the cathedral. The label features a horse brand icon in honor of one of Moore’s earliest brands. The brand’s many flourishes and motifs were heavily inspired by vintage advertisements and stationery from the Thomas S. Moore archives.

name: Carroll, Daniel
title: Humana Value-based Care Report Microsite
challenge_solution: In creating the 2020 Value-based Care Report, the design team was challenged to take a dry subject—an annual update on healthcare payment and care models—and transform it into an engaging web-based experience that would inspire physician audiences to consider broad changes to their practice's operations. The report uses real-life patient and physician case studies to connect emotionally with the reader, showing an honest and engaging portrayal of the pros and cons of switching to a value-based care model. Then, dynamic infographics and charts make the data more relevant, interactive and informative.  Microsite URL: https://digital.humana.com/VBCReport/

name: Clark, Jason
title: Dr. Marcum's Nutraceuticals
challenge_solution: Dr. Brian Marcum came to us with a solid product, big ideas, and an aggressive timeline. After spending years developing his virus-fighting supplement, Dr. Marcum needed help getting this product into the hands of homemakers, 9-5'ers, and anyone else who can’t afford to take a sick day — and fast! By accelerating our Brand Strategy and Identity process, we gave the product a complete rebrand, built an eCommerce website, and developed and implemented a marketing strategy all before the end of cold & flu season.

name: Zimmer, Jim
title: Dark Matter Coffee Core Brands Redesign
challenge_solution: Dark Matter Coffee’s long-established core brands–Unicorn Blood, A Love Supreme, Starry Eyes, and Machete–make up their Portfolio Blends foundation. After many years without a design update, they were due for a reboot. Cue the mind-bending, galaxy-hopping, sci-fi-centric, creative brief.

name: Suhr, Jessica
title: Avenues Unlimited Website
challenge_solution: Avenues Unlimited provides counseling services in Louisville, KY. We designed and developed a fully responsive website that makes clients feel hopeful and uplifted while creating a home-base that stands apart from any one person so that the business can attract new talent and continue to grow. Throughout the website, we added subtle animations and interactions including the animated logo to better engage site visitors and affirm the company’s modern point of view.  https://avenuesunlimited.com/
credit_1: Creative Direction & Design: Jessica Suhr - Perennial Creative Co.
credit_2: Photography: Amy Barber - Bluegrass Bebe Photography

name: Collins, Taylor
title: ZWN Brewing Company
challenge_solution: Imagine your client makes authentic ethnic food or beverage products. Your assignment is to design a series of labels for three flavors or varieties of condiments or beverages. The packaging should project an ethnically authentic feel, while also appealing to a broader market than consumers from that culture.

name: Suhr, Jessica
title: Two Worlds Whiskey Website
challenge_solution: Two Worlds Whiskey is a luxury whiskey crafted exclusively for the French market. We designed and developed a fully responsive website that feels luxe and high-end so that Two Worlds can establish themselves in the French liquor marketplace as a luxury whiskey brand. Throughout the website, we added subtle animations and interactions to better engage site visitors and affirm the company’s high-end position in the market.  https://twoworldswhiskey.com/
credit_1: Website Design & Development: Jessica Suhr - Perennial Creative Co.
credit_2: Branding & Packaging Design: Chad Michael Studio

name: Dixon, Brianna
title: Wild Wine
challenge_solution: The concept for the imagery was to play off the idea of embracing your "spirit" animal. The overall concept of the packaging was more of the "unboxing" experience. This design was created to appeal to a classy demographic. The packaging is not just a etched wooden box but, a refined bottled of wine paired with an opener. This lavish wine is perfect for a refined palette and ideal for gifting.

name: Wiesen, Mitch
title: Shop JennRon
challenge_solution: Shop JennRon is a new kind of thrift store where quality garments are hand crafted using vintage and dead-stock fabrics to not only fit but also to feel empowering on every kind of body. Shop Jennron is a body positive, community centered space where vintage is made "just for you."   The challenge was to create a brand identity as hip and fun and welcoming (and vintage inspired) as the brand itself.

name: Wiesen, Mitch
title: Tzedek, Tzedek, Tirdof! (Justice, Justice, You Shall Pursue it!)
challenge_solution: The challenge was to find a way for Bend the Arc: Jewish Action Louisville (a progressive Jewish organization fighting for justice for all) to highlight the urgency of defunding the police and support the Black community in Louisville in the wake of Breonna Taylor's murder.   We solved this challenge by creating a zine/tool of political education that connects fundamental Jewish values to the fight for racial justice, specifically Black liberation. The zine was distributed at Jewish centers, marches and rallies, and is available for free download on several sites, including mitchwiesen.com.
credit_2: Bend The Arc: Jewish Action Louisville

name: Becker, Ava
title: Dala Sparkling Water
school_company: University of Louisville Hite Art Institute
challenge_solution: This challenge was to incorporate a culture into a variety of beverage packaging design. This project utilized traditional Swedish symbols, like the Dala horse and Scandinavian rosemaling patterns, in order to fulfill the project requirements. The packaging had to have an ethnically authentic feel while also appealing to a broader market outside of consumers for that culture.

name: Zimmer, Jim
title: The Seafood Lady
challenge_solution: Branding and identity system for The Seafood Lady restaurant. For this branding project, we elevated a much-loved Louisville mainstay to the next level without losing the soul of its creator.
credit_2: Nathan Weaver: Graphic Designer and Illustrator

name: Zimmer, Jim
title: Bar Vetti Hospitality
challenge_solution: Branding and environmental design for Bar Vetti hospitality. Our visuals for the updated branding, signage, and collateral lean towards witty, original illustrations in soft pastels and olives. Typography is a mashup of Italian Futurism, International Style, and Art Deco. It's a brand that's designed to make you smile while you enjoy your piccata.
credit_3: Nathan Weaver: Graphic Designer and Illustrator

name: Zimmer, Jim
title: Arami Cocktails
challenge_solution: Branding and packaging design for Arami ready-to-drink cocktails. Taking mainstays from their unique sake cocktail menu, we designed packaging that brings the brand beverages home.
credit_1: Jim Zimmer: Creative Director and Graphic Designer

name: Zimmer, Jim
title: People Power Cans
challenge_solution: Beer label design and illustration for Three Floyds Brewery. Created to benefit the partnership between craft breweries and the ACLU. Illustrations were inspired by the great underground political cartoonist Skip Williamson.
credit_1: Jim Zimmer: Creative Director and Graphic Designer

name: Hackworth, Jordan
title: Squalor Appalachian People Publication
challenge_solution: Poor, illiterate, and dirty. Cliché stereotypes like these have followed Appalachian people for centuries, yet shaking those won’t come any time soon. “But, Isn’t squalor a negative term?” The answer is yes. Squalor is the combination of poor, illiterate, and dirty. None of which are a part of an Appalachian’s identity. We've seen words that were once used negatively then turn to an endearing term within the community it was once used against. Taking a word used to degrade and belittle Appalachian’s, now to uplift and evoke new and creative thinking. It’s not owning our stereotypes but instead redefining them.

name: Langford, Sarah
title: Dead-Nettle
challenge_solution: Dead-Nettle is a subscription box containing apothecary-themed cocktail mix kits. Because of the deconstructed nature of mix kits, the user gets to imitate the experience of apothecary practice, creating a fun hands-on aspect that would be lost if the product were pre-made or served in a bar setting. The illustrations used are inspired by 19th century press plates, while the photographic style is a nod to Carravagio’s still-life painting style, taking inspiration from his use of soft, sfumato techniques to draw emphasis to the subject of the image.

name: Brinker, Kyle
title: Boothby’s Minigolf & Scotch
challenge_solution: Boothby’s is dedicated to Mrs. Boothby, who, in 1867, rebelled against the Gentleman’s Golf Club at St. Andrews in Scotland by starting her own Ladies’ Putting Club—the first ever minigolf course. At the time, women were not permitted to lift their arms above their shoulders, so the putting club allowed women to participate in a full miniature golf game.  Boothby’s Minigolf and Scotch embraces her rebellious spirit and elegance. The brand also celebrates women’s suffrage as Mrs. Boothby embodied the desire for women’s equality that soon after brought about the suffrage movement.

name: Langford, Sarah
title: Water Fountain
challenge_solution: A kinetic typographic piece serving as a rhythmic lyric video for "Water Fountain," a track by Tune Yards. I aimed to create a visual representation of the feeling the song evokes. I attempted this through an illustration style reminiscent to a child's paper-cutouts, which could be layered, disassembled, and basically used as puppets throughout the song. I paired this with a jittery motion applied to all assets, in pace with the rhythm of the song, in an attempt to elevate the energy throughout the piece.
credit_1: Water Fountain by Tune Yards - Song Credit

name: Goodman, Glenn
title: Cold Smoke Bagels - Appetizing Store Poster Campaign
challenge_solution: Common in New York City, Jewish appetizing stores focus on serving up authentic Kosher comfort food. In 2019, Cold Smoke Bagels opened as the first and only appetizing store in Louisville. This poster campaign built a tailored and sophisticated brand look using the colors of the existing logo and crisp photography of mouthwatering Jewish classics. Clever headlines rounded out the executions, creating an elevated, yet approachable campaign for this local treasure.

name: Goodman, Glenn
title: Passionist Earth & Spirit Center - Social Campaign
challenge_solution: The Passionist Earth & Spirit Center is nonprofit, interfaith spirituality center that’s deeply rooted in the idea that everything is interconnected. During the COVID-19 pandemic, almost all of their course offerings were forced online. This social campaign featured a unique illustration style to stand out from the typical Instagram stories users would encounter during their daily browsing. A peaceful color scheme was based on the main brand hues, while overall messaging was used to communicate that literally anyone could benefit from a few moments of peace during a stressful time.

name: Goodman, Glenn
title: Monogram Appliances - Monogram Experience Center Folder
challenge_solution: Monogram is a luxury appliance brand whose tagline is "Elevate Everything." This means that every exposure to the brand must be held to high levels of sophistication and expectation. The Monogram Experience Center is a physical location where designers, dealers and salespeople are invited to learn about the brand and interact with products. As such, all materials supporting the MEC must meet the exacting standards set forth by the brand. The Power Agency redesigned all marketing materials, including a comprehensive folder and supporting documents, with careful attention to detail - including paper selections, varnishes and user experience - in mind.

name: Lee, Molly
title: New Wave Coffee Co
challenge_solution: The design challenge for this project was to create a coffee company's brand identity and packaging components. I named my simulated company “New Wave Coffee Co” to symbolize the ever-changing trends in the coffee industry. The packaging design process began with the idea of creating a cold brew coffee blend. Cold brew is the most recent trend in the coffee industry as well as my favorite way to make and drink coffee. The packaging includes a cold brew blend coffee bag, an espresso blend coffee bag, and a hand-lettered logo.

name: Lucas, Kaley
title: A Civil Rights Tour of Louisville
school_company: University of Louisville Hite Art Institute
challenge_solution: The project challenge was to design a book about a Civil Rights History Tour of Louisville. Copy was supplied from Cate Fosl’s guide and images were found from a variety of historical sources. While this project focused on the use of grid and typography, it was also really important to portray the right tonality for a serious topic such as Civil Rights. This tonality was achieved by use of ephemera and overlaying.

name: Perez, Andy
title: 2021 Kentucky Derby Festival Poster - "Going Up
challenge_solution: I was commissioned to create an image for a commemorative/promotional poster for the 2021 Kentucky Derby Festival in Louisville, KY. The festival requested an image that embodied the excitement of the festival and honored the traditions of the past. This poster is sold as a standalone item, and it is also used as the foundation for a variety of related merchandise. I created an image that is fun, bright, and inclusive of many aspects of the festival. In addition to my typical painted paper, I was also able to use pieces of past festival posters in this collaged artwork.
credit_1: Illustrated and Designed by Andy Perez

name: Spalding, Andrew
title: Oregon Child Abuse Solutions Brand Identity
challenge_solution: Oregon Child Abuse Solutions (OCAS) sought to educate Oregonians about the prevalence of abuse, share proven methods of child abuse prevention, and mobilize expertise and resources in order to provide adequate care to all Oregon children.  To expand their awareness and impact, an energetic new identity was created from simple patterns and shapes, featuring a hand-drawn typeface reflecting the care and passion that OCAS shows day in and day out. A new website was created to act as an educational resource and inspire change from the organization’s partners, donors, and the community at large.

name: Spalding, Andrew
title: Oregon Child Abuse Solutions Brand Identity
challenge_solution: Oregon Child Abuse Solutions (OCAS) sought to educate Oregonians about the prevalence of abuse, share proven methods of child abuse prevention, and mobilize expertise and resources in order to provide adequate care to all Oregon children.  To expand their awareness and impact, an energetic new identity was created from simple patterns and shapes, featuring a hand-drawn typeface reflecting the care and passion that OCAS shows day in and day out. A new website was created to act as an educational resource and inspire change from the organization’s partners, donors, and the community at large.

name: Spalding, Andrew
title: Oregon Child Abuse Solutions Website
challenge_solution: Oregon Child Abuse Solutions (OCAS) sought to educate Oregonians about the prevalence of abuse, share proven methods of child abuse prevention, and mobilize expertise and resources in order to provide adequate care to all Oregon children.  After creating their new brand identity we looked to expand their awareness and impact by designing and developing a new website to act as an educational resource and inspire change from the organization’s partners, donors, and the community at large.

name: Spalding, Andrew
title: Genentech Newsletter Illustrated Infographic
challenge_solution: An illustration created for biotech company Genentech's newsletter creatively outlining where their philanthropic efforts have been directed during the past year.

name: Spalding, Andrew
title: AIGA Awards 2020 Brand Identity
challenge_solution: Branding created for the 2020 AIGA Louisville Awards. Design is inherently subjective, having “winners” despite concrete metrics, with each viewer seeing a design from a different background and perspective. We decided to lean into those gray areas and create a theme and brand centered around subjectivity.  A series of designs were created each featuring a different background made from ink splatters and brush strokes reflecting the messiness intrinsic in the process of creation. On top was a design made from different boxes that played with geometry and perspective, forcing the viewer to look from different angles and reexamine their viewpoint.

name: Spalding, Elizabeth Perry
title: Goat Rodeo Resorts 2
challenge_solution: This project is a self-promotion book featuring the work of Louisville-based Photographer Thomas Hart Shelby who has been described by Michael Vanderbyl as, "captivating, witty, and inventive."   A wide range of disciplines and background has led to the narrative approach that Thom brings to his present day commercial work. He has been described as a genuine artist possessed of a singular creative gift, matched by the diligence of a true professional.
credit_2: Studio of Origin  21 Skye Design, Elizabeth Perry Spalding

name: Spalding, Andrew
title: Stay Strong Louisville COVID-19 Relief Campaign
challenge_solution: The “Stay Strong Louisville” Campaign was created for the Louisville Department of Public Health support their COVID relief efforts.  Focused on building trust with the more affected yet underserved communities, we used design, and imagery that would reflect those audiences, creating a more grassroots feel than typical government initiatives.  We used bright green to draw attention and echo the color representing COVID, with custom typography and cut-up imagery. Photography and video were shot on location with residents in their neighborhoods. The campaign has been translated into six languages with a landing page that easily flips between English and Spanish.

name: Seibert, Lesa
title: BLM Video
challenge_solution: A pro bono social media ad produced in conjunction with Louisville’s Black Lives Matter group. Shot at a local school, the video addresses the importance of supporting minority youth in addressing systemic racial injustice.

name: Pallmann, Susan
title: Best Foot Forward
challenge_solution: Students were instructed to take a "blue law" and create an advertising campaign for it across both digital and large-scale (billboard) media.   In Washington State, the harassment of bigfoot is a felony punishable by fine.  Rather than taking a negative tone, "Best Foot Forward" reframes the issue, instead inviting people to be kind to bigfoot or have good "bigfoot etiquette." To accomplish this, Bigfoot is portrayed as a friendly, approachable character through the use of clay imagery and the audience is invited to "put their best foot forward."   A live site exists at: https://susanpallmann.github.io/foot-forward/

name: Weaver, Nathan
title: Hog Father Pizza
challenge_solution: Naming, custom type, and illustration for Louisville's newest pizza shop located in the old Hall's Cafeteria building in the heart of Butchertown.

name: Seibert, Lesa
title: The Grainwright Posters Campaign
challenge_solution: The Grainwright is a small artisan sourdough-bread and pizza-making company. Started on a shoestring budget, we helped them draw broad exposure with hand-crafted-looking ads and defiant (but witty) messaging. The campaign included a shittily-built-but-cool website the client put together supplemented by a range of for-purchase collateral.

name: Weaver, Nathan
title: Radio Branding
challenge_solution: Naming, branding, and packaging for start-up health and wellness brand Radio

name: Seibert, Lesa
title: NBA2Lou Website
challenge_solution: Louisville is a college-sports town, but like many cities its size it’s trying to attract professional teams. NBA2Lou is an ambitious initiative with two different — very different — aspirations. One is to attract early grassroots community support by presenting the franchise as something "sexy and cool”; and the other is to present the investment opportunity as something highly sophisticated and polished to billionaires / potential owners.  https://nba2lou.com/

name: Seibert, Lesa
title: I Can't Breathe Video
challenge_solution: With his dying words “I can’t breathe,” George Floyd became a global symbol of racist police militancy and aggression to hundreds of millions. This simple video captures that terrible moment with poignancy and honesty.

name: Seibert, Lesa
title: Family & Children's Place Posters
challenge_solution: Family & Children's Place is the state’s largest family advocacy group, and has a national reputation for its forensics work. Unfortunately, the other side of this value involves dysfunctional relationships, distressed families, and abused kids, things that are difficult to communicate. These internal posters incorporate Kentucky flora and fauna with profiles of children, anchored by the simple but clever message “Raising hope,” positioning the center as somewhere that effects the positive change, which leads to a richer tomorrow.

name: Spalding, Andrew
title: Stay Strong Louisville COVID-19 Relief Website
challenge_solution: The Louisville Department of Health and Wellness had created a massive resource center for all COVID-19 related information and resources, but unfortunately it was dense, confusing, and difficult to navigate.  Our team created a central hub for residents to easily find the information they needed. It's design and messaging would reflect the campaign throughout the city, and help get the right resources to the right people.

name: Carroll, Daniel
title: Humana Value-based Care Report Microsite
challenge_solution: In creating the 2020 Value-based Care Report, the design team was challenged to take a dry subject—an annual update on healthcare payment and care models—and transform it into an engaging web-based experience that would inspire physician audiences to consider broad changes to their practice's operations. The report uses real-life patient and physician case studies to connect emotionally with the reader, showing an honest and engaging portrayal of the pros and cons of switching to a value-based care model. Then, dynamic infographics and charts make the data more relevant, interactive and informative.  Microsite URL: https://digital.humana.com/VBCReport/

name: Carroll, Daniel
title: Humana 2020 Annual Report
challenge_solution: The Humana Annual Report is released yearly to share the company’s financial performance, and what contributed to it, with stakeholders and the general public. In 2020, the design team was challenged to not only capture the complex climate of the year, but also introduce human care—Humana’s customer-centric communication and brand strategy which aims to differentiate Humana from other health insurers.

name: Smith, Mackenzie
title: Five Things
school_company: University of Louisville Hite Art Institute
challenge_solution: This project is inspired by Five Things, a podcast about the objects that define us, from 89.3 WFPL and Louisville Public Media. I was tasked with designing a book form featuring five things that tell my story.

name: Carroll, Daniel
title: Humana 2019 Inclusion & Diversity Report
challenge_solution: Showcasing Humana’s continued efforts to cultivate a diverse and inclusion culture, the Inclusion & Diversity (I&D) Annual Report was released in March 2020 to provide a comprehensive, creative overview of the company’s progress as it relates to corporate strategy. Pay equity, non-discrimination, and employee assistance programs are just the beginning for Humana, who strives to create an equitable world for both workplace and communities. Using imagery and unique Humana visuals, including our Big H, we worked to fully represent our range of diverse associates who make up our company through Humana-owned imagery.

name: Carroll, Daniel
title: Humana Proactive Care Campaign
challenge_solution: At the end of 2020, Humana wanted to communicate to Medicare members that it was still recommended to maintain medical visits during the COVID-19 pandemic. In order to remind members to stop medical distancing while practicing social distancing, we created a national broadcast TV spot that covered these proof points in a simple, animated illustration style with a friendly voiceover. To supplement the TV spot, an out of home campaign was launched including billboards, retail signage, a full-page USA Today ad, and social media animated posts.

name: Carroll, Daniel
title: Humana Derby 2020 Commemorative Gift
challenge_solution: In the past, Humana’s c-suite executives invited guests to come enjoy the Derby experience with them. In 2020, rather than celebrating in person, the challenge was bringing the spirit of the Kentucky Derby to the safety of their homes. We were asked to create a memorable experience through a gift box including elements of the Derby. We struck a balance between Humana branded and Derby elements through messaging and clear logo usage on the front. The interior cards were clearly branded Humana and used our design elements of a photo texture to tie back to the Kentucky Derby.

name: Taylor, Kijah
title: BSU Club
challenge_solution: There actually wasn't much of a description for this challenge except for us to create a visual representation of what Black History Month meant to us in general. I created a design that represented what Black History Month meant to me.

name: Carroll, Daniel
title: David Jones Commemorative Event Thank You Gift
challenge_solution: When David A. Jones passed away in 2019, we were asked to design a suite of materials inviting family, friends and guests of Humana to celebrate his life. The invitation was designed to honor his contributions, using elements of the Humana corporate tower in the invitation design. As a thank you gift, a coin with Mr. Jones’ face was created and mailed to his closest family and guests. The coin was encased in a wooden box with engraved letters and a copy of the plaque that sits in his honor outside of the Humana tower.

name: Spalding, Andrew
title: Tipping Point Communications Brand Identity Expansion
challenge_solution: Tipping Point Communications is an award winning Public Relations & Media Agency, but recently they have been having a harder time gaining new clients, and they felt their brand didn't fit their quality of work.  The refreshed brand is centers on Tipping Point as the leading light for their clients as they guide them on their journey. The photography is used as a focal point in this system to visually tell the story of Tipping Point. The combination of the bright colors and photography paired with the Swiss typeface and grid structure creates a clean yet energetic brand.

name: Carroll, Daniel
title: David Jones Commemorative Event Thank You Gift
challenge_solution: When David A. Jones passed away in 2019, we were asked to design a suite of materials inviting family, friends and guests of Humana to celebrate his life. The invitation was designed to honor his contributions, using elements of the Humana corporate tower in the invitation design. As a thank you gift, a coin with Mr. Jones’ face was created and mailed to his closest family and guests. The coin was encased in a wooden box with engraved letters and a copy of the plaque that sits in his honor outside of the Humana tower.

name: Carroll, Daniel
title: Humana COVID-19 Response - Mask Kit Campaign
challenge_solution: During the height of the COVID-19 pandemic, Humana wanted to ensure their members had correct information and guidance while navigating the uncertainty of daily life. We designed branded masks that were paired with an insert of CDC recommendations and mailed to millions of members. At the same time, social media animations were posted with to communicate reminders during that difficult season, as well as a public service announcement full-page USA Today ad.

name: Spalding, Andrew
title: Space Tango Website Design and Development
challenge_solution: Space Tango had a strong brand, but their website was confusing. They positioned themselves as the more approachable side of the Low Earth Orbit space (LEO) category, however their language did not reflect that. Confusing website navigation paired with complicated language and ‘space jargon’ was hurting their brand and putting off new new customers wanting to enter the LEO market.  We designed and developed an exciting website full of motion, interactivity, and engaging UI, that would allow Space Tango to stand along side the industry titans and hold their own.

name: Carroll, Daniel
title: Humana Medicaid Kentucky 2020 Campaign
challenge_solution: Humana wanted an out of home campaign to drive market awareness of our Medicaid coverage and new plan name: Humana Healthy Horizons. We developed billboards, bus shelters, grassroots flyers, grocery cart signage, social media and target digital display creative that differentiated from our traditional Medicare audience but still felt cohesive to the overall brand. We also conducted a photoshoot that would provide ownable assets that felt unique from our competitors and felt realistic to our target audience.

name: Carroll, Daniel
title: Humana Medicare Annual Enrollment Agent Materials
challenge_solution: Each year, Humana provides a large collection of carefully curated marketing materials to assist health insurance sales agents in finding seniors their best suited Medicare plan during the federal open enrollment period from November 1st through December 15th. The 2021 Agent Materials incorporated Humana’s new “human care” brand positioning and provided a fresh take on Humana’s brand identity for the campaign to build awareness and trust with consumers in the Medicare marketplace. The new design and branding helped maintain the enrollment materials as rated #1 by health insurance sales agents for a fourth consecutive year.

name: Hearne, Joseph
title: Shangri-La's Tattoo Emporium Branding
challenge_solution: Robbie Hernandez opened his studio in 2012 with the purpose of creating the antithesis of the typical tattoo shop(s). After eight years, he felt his message was getting lost. In order to continue in the direction of the original vision, he sought out a rebrand.   The original name–7 Shangri-Las Art Emporium–was changed to Shangri-La’s Tattoo Emporium. This allowed them to maintain recognition while also clarifying their message. A new identity was then designed to support that message. It's inspired by Tibetan monastery life and represents the tranquility found at the quiet tattoo studio located on the riverfront of Newburgh, Indiana.

name: Stewart, Zachary
title: Maker's Mark Playing Cards
challenge_solution: 2020, as an especially crummy, isolating year, called for some special attention to what would be the latest installment in Maker’s Mark’s annual holiday gift to its brand ambassadors. Something analog and familiar that invited group participation felt natural after a year spent digitally, alien, and alone. The project quickly grew from a simple deck into a complex, illustrated celebration of the brand. Recipes, portraits of the founding family and interesting facts about Maker’s are woven into the designs for a deck that opens itself up a little more each time you play with it, even if it’s only solitaire.

name: Stewart, Zachary
title: Maker's Mark Playing Cards
challenge_solution: 2020, as an especially crummy, isolating year, called for some special attention to what would be the latest installment in Maker’s Mark’s annual holiday gift to its brand ambassadors. Something analog and familiar that invited group participation felt natural after a year spent digitally, alien, and alone. The project quickly grew from a simple deck into a complex, illustrated celebration of the brand. Recipes, portraits of the founding family and interesting facts about Maker’s are woven into the designs for a deck that opens itself up a little more each time you play with it, even if it’s only solitaire.

name: Stewart, Zachary
title: Diabetes Leadership Council/Diabetes Patient Advocacy Coalition Identity
challenge_solution: The Diabetes Leadership Council and the Diabetes Patient Advocacy Coalition wanted a new visual identity. The Diabetes Leadership Council (DLC) primarily promotes the education of diabetes and the Diabetes Patient Advocacy Coalition (DPAC) advocates on behalf of patients and their rights. The overall goal was to update the looks of their brands as well as make a clear affiliation between the two organizations. They wanted it to be obvious to anyone who sees the two logos side by side to know they are connected, yet offer a clear distinction between them.

name: Kuhn, Adam
title: Common Good Rebrand
challenge_solution: Common Good is an after school community in a low-income neighborhood in North Lexington. Over 75 students, grades K-12, come through its doors daily to learn, play, share a warm meal, and connect. Students and families feel safe and loved. Leaders emerge.   We wanted to help Common Good share their stories. To communicate that they are more than an after-school program. They invest in students and whole families; they’re a beacon of hope in an area of concentrated poverty. We created a visual and verbal identity to rally around, with illustrations inspired by their art and language by their experiences.
credit_2: Bullhorn, Anne Dean Dotson, Language Director
credit_3: Space, Place & Southern Grace Photo, Photography (provided)

name: Kuhn, Adam
title: Community Response Coalition of Kentucky Rebrand
challenge_solution: The Community Response Coalition of Kentucky believes that a good community helps its neighbors. They provide support to families negatively affected by immigration enforcement in Central Kentucky.   We partnered with CRCKY to refresh their visual identity. To show their strength and bold determination to take care of their immigrant friends and neighbors. Inspired by their diverse community of unique perspectives, five of our designers participated in a design sprint. When you set a timer, we learned that you only have to create — on a gut feeling and some passion.

name: Spalding, Skye
title: World Wildlife Fund Postage Stamp and Postcard Collection
challenge_solution: The objective of this assignment was to design a series of United States Postal Service stamps and a set of corresponding postcards for the World Wildlife Fund. Each stamp and postcard features a single endangered species. For these illustrations, my goal was to emulate a 60s style of illustration akin to Peter Max to inject some whimsy and fun into the assignment. I wanted to remind the user of the beauty of these animals as well as the personality and color they bring to our world.

name: Kuhn, Adam
title: Peer Pressure Bullhorn Impact Report
challenge_solution: We believe in good work. The trouble is that it can be hard to do good work over and over. Not just work that is effective, but work that makes a social and environmental impact.   Peer Pressure, our impact report, is a collection of stories about learning from each other. Stories about our motivations, experiences, and ideas. About building a better company and pushing each other to create the future we want to live in. It is a look back at the past two years — at our impact on each other, our partners, and our community.
credit_2: Bullhorn, Jenny Cobb, Associate Art Director

name: Kuhn, Adam
title: Screamin’ Mimi’s Rebrand
challenge_solution: We have strong feelings about our favorite foods. Sometimes our foods should have strong feelings, too. Screamin’ Mimi’s asked us to translate the core tenet of their brand — a genuine, messy togetherness — to a digital age.  We learned about Mimi, an undeterred matriarch with a hell of a lot of zest. And we learned what made this salsa more than just salsa: a sweet and spicy duality that mirrored Mimi’s persona. We reinvigorated the brand language and design to capture this personality. Then we designed packaging, provided photography, and created a website as lively as the brand itself.
credit_1: Bullhorn, Jenny Cobb, Associate Art Director

name: Kuhn, Adam
title: Waterfront Park Rebrand
challenge_solution: Waterfront Park is not a city park. Once a bleak and environmentally-compromised area, it’s now an independent, nonprofit park. It’s also one of the most diverse places in the city. And it’s growing — reclaiming an inaccessible plot of waterfront and expanding to West Louisville.   We created a visual identity, verbal identity, and website to tackle a major perception problem. They aren’t a city park, so we set out to clearly differentiate them. And because they are independent, they need support. We made sure they were equipped to clearly communicate who they are and why they need to stick around.
credit_2: Bullhorn, Jenny Cobb, Associate Art Director
credit_3: Bullhorn, Anne Dean Dotson, Language Director

name: Deckel, Steve
title: Café Endless Optimist
challenge_solution: Café Appliances asked us to design a kitchen set to illustrate how the pandemic is changing kitchen design.   D&M's lead designer's solution took inspiration from how Dior changed fashion with their New Look after World War II. People had been so down during the war that they were ready to hit the scene again and express themselves. Dior’s opulent look, bold colors and big volume in the fabrics was the ticket.   The endless optimist kitchen is a bold statement and embrace of optimism in kitchen design, through color, waves, curves, textures and materiality come together in the design.   https://www.today.com/food/how-pandemic-changing-kitchen-design-2021-today-t211769

name: Feimer, Tiffany
title: DesigHERS Conference Visual Identity
school_company: University of Louisville Hite Art Institute
challenge_solution: Inspired by my design heroes print publication and the AIGA Women Lead Initiative, DesigHERS is a hypothetical all-women design conference that is dedicated to promoting and recognizing the success of women in design. Incorporating duo-tone images, overlaying squares, and typography, this visual identity embraces the challenging building-blocks women encounter in the design industry. Deliverables include set design, conference program, posters, lanyards, shirts, notebook, and tote bag.

name: Braley, Michael
title: Electric Vehicle Charging Icon
challenge_solution: This icon represents one of the Pando Days 2021 challenges:  "How might we re-imagine mobility and deploy access to EV charging across the Pasadena region?"  Pando Days brings together the most creative minds within higher education from the arts, humanities, sciences, and technology  to tackle the biggest sustainability challenges facing Southern California.  pandopopulus.com/programs/pando-days-21/

name: Feimer, Tiffany
title: Aaron's Brand Identity
school_company: University of Louisville Hite Art Institute
challenge_solution: As a leader of lease-purchase solutions of name-brand furniture, electronics, and home appliances, Aaron’s needed a brand renovation to remain relevant among other retailers. The goal for this re-imagining of their brand was to create a modern visual system that would increase the attention of both millennials and existing core customers. In addition to seeking out more customers, this new identity and guidelines would aid their ability to become more relevant among other retailers. This new brand identity includes a new logo and visual identity system, stationery, website, print advertisements, uniforms, delivery vehicle wrap, and a brand standards manual.

name: Stead, Spencer
title: Two Brothers Baking
challenge_solution: Tasked with the creation of a visual identity and branding system to fulfill a product offering gap in supermarket baking supply offerings, Two Brothers Baking seeks to provide the baking essentials to the up-and-coming at-home amateur baker. Inspired by the foundational ingredients of baking, the design focuses on the creation and repetition of design elements to emulate the use of basic ingredients as well as the skills gained through repetitious practice while more effectively cultivating brand recognition growth, a battle many new products face but Two Brothers Baking overcomes.

name: Jaworski, Candace
title: Under the Bridge
challenge_solution: Students had to create a black and white street photograph in their Journalistic and Editorial Photography class.

name: Curry, Brett
title: RocketJar Web Site
challenge_solution: RocketJar is a digital fundraising platform with a focus on customization and ease of use. The company's main customers are high schools and small universities.   The site needed to show the separate features of the platform, while also including a blog for industry related articles. Unfortunately, the pandemic has caused a pause in the project, which is still awaiting development.

name: Jaworski, Candace
title: Heirloom Herbal Tea Brand Guide
challenge_solution: The student was challenged with creating a brand for a beverage (in this case tea) and then had to develop the brand standards for it as though it they would be provided in a corporate situation.

name: Allison, Olivia
title: Vision University Brand Standards
school_company: University of Louisville Hite Art Institute
challenge_solution: The goal of this project was to design and create one comprehensive identity system for the hypothetical merger of four private colleges. Vision University branding brings the four colleges into one voice through a series of campaigns projecting beyond just a logo. Vision University branding extends to brochures, billboards, social media ads, website, and more.

name: Jaworski, Candace
title: To Kill a Mockingbird
challenge_solution: The student was challenged with choosing a classic novel then creating a new book cover design for it.

name: Jaworski, Candace
title: Children Not Soldiers
challenge_solution: To create a social cause poster on a subject matter that we strongly believe in. I am from Myanmar and this represents the violence happening against innocent people by the military.

name: Jaworski, Candace
title: Sun Splash
challenge_solution: Students were challenged to create a beverage brand and packaging. This student chose a healthy alternative beverage with natural citrus flavors geared towards children.

name: Jaworski, Candace
title: Sun Splash Campaign
challenge_solution: Students were challenged to identify a target audience, in this case young children and their mothers, and create an advertising campaign that would appeal to them. This student did print ads as they would appear in Parents magazine and Out-of-Home that would be seen in a mall leading up to a store like Walgreens. The brand illustrates young women in an aspirational light with big career dreams.

name: Allison, Olivia
title: Render Capital Brand Identity
challenge_solution: Render Capital is a fund in the Louisville/Southern Indiana area that seeks to connect and bring capital to local entrepreneurs. Because traditional resources for funding can be perceived as sterile and masculine in regard to tonality, the goal of Render Capital's branding was to create a bright, inviting, and more inclusive tone.

name: Allison, Olivia
title: Azalea App
school_company: University of Louisville Hite Art Institute
challenge_solution: When shopping for floral arrangements, whether it be for yourself or someone else, most people don't know where to begin. Azalea offers users the opportunity to explore fresh and dried floral arrangements, create custom bouquets, and take a quiz to discover what types of flowers/bouquets best match their situation--all from their phone. Azalea offers a fun and simplified process of selecting and buying flowers to ensure consumers are satisfied with their floral arrangements, no matter the situation.

name: Rookard, Kyra
title: Shrub Subscription Box
challenge_solution: The goal of this project was to create an original subscription box concept along with unique branding and a finalized package design. To meet this challenge, I created Shrub, The Shrub-scription Box. The concept of Shrub is a subscription box "made for plant lovers everywhere" that appeals primarily to young professionals as well as general plant enthusiasts. The modern, nature-inspired branding is a reflection of current trends found in the houseplant market. By incorporating this branding extensively throughout the package, I was able to create a cohesive piece that communicates a sense of nature and appeals to this demographic.

name: Allison, Olivia
title: The Trippy Chicken
school_company: University of Louisville Hite Art Institute
challenge_solution: Take-out packaging contains an unnecessary amount of single-use plastics, foams, etc. The goal of The Trippy Chicken was to create take-out packaging that was sustainable and recognizable as a brand. The Trippy Chicken is a hypothetical food truck brand that offers sustainable packaging through the use of uncoated, 100% post-consumer-waste paper as well as utilizing a color paper to reduce the use of ink. The paper packaging also minimizes the use of single-use plastics.

name: LaRue, Keith
title: Never Give Up
challenge_solution: In the midst of the pandemic, the awakening of justice for BIPOC began (again). I took my camera and started shooting to capture the beauty of Unity our great city displays. Theses images speak volumes to what the community is about, contrary to what the media portrays. My series is of 6 images (only uploaded two). I named it Never Give Up, because we have been fighting the same fight for many years. We must Never Give Up and fight for unity and justice.
